meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: Job Growth Surged and Wages Rose in March Wages climbed and job growth rose last month by the largest numbers this year, the Labor Department said, as strong consumer spending led to hiring in restaurants, bars, department stores and educational services. The unemployment rate fell to 4.4 percent from 4.5 percent.

China Complaint Called Near The Bush administration appears close to filing a formal trade complaint against China, after months of prodding the Chinese government to crack down on pirated copies of films, music and software.
Vonage Gets a Reprieve A federal court gave Vonage a reprieve shortly after a lower court barred it from enrolling new subscribers.
At 96, a Writer Is Discovered With publication of his memoir of a poor childhood in an English mill town, Harry Bernstein, above, has enjoyed ''a lot of exciting, interesting days.''
Networks Condemn Imus The radio and television networks that carry Don Imus's show deplored remarks he had made about the Rutgers women's basketball team. Mr. Imus apologized.
Keeping the Faith Pope Benedict XVI says re-Christianizing Europe is critical to the fate of the church and to the fate of the Continent itself.
The Poetry of Exile The Nobel Prize winner Derek Walcott's ''Selected Poems'' shows him as a man caught between two races and two worlds.
It's Over, Tony With the final season of ''The Sopranos'' beginning, Alessandra Stanley looks back.

Job Growth Surged and Wages Rose in March Wages climbed and job growth rose last month by the largest numbers this year, the Labor Department said, as strong consumer spending led to hiring in restaurants, bars, department stores and educational services. The unemployment rate fell to 4.4 percent from 4.5 percent.

China Complaint Called Near The Bush administration appears close to filing a formal trade complaint against China, after months of prodding the Chinese government to crack down on pirated copies of films, music and software.
Vonage Gets a Reprieve A federal court gave Vonage a reprieve shortly after a lower court barred it from enrolling new subscribers.
At 96, a Writer Is Discovered With publication of his memoir of a poor childhood in an English mill town, Harry Bernstein, above, has enjoyed ''a lot of exciting, interesting days.''
Networks Condemn Imus The radio and television networks that carry Don Imus's show deplored remarks he had made about the Rutgers women's basketball team. Mr. Imus apologized.
Keeping the Faith Pope Benedict XVI says re-Christianizing Europe is critical to the fate of the church and to the fate of the Continent itself.
The Poetry of Exile The Nobel Prize winner Derek Walcott's ''Selected Poems'' shows him as a man caught between two races and two worlds.
It's Over, Tony With the final season of ''The Sopranos'' beginning, Alessandra Stanley looks back.
